I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2011  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide Yunnan 
Province  with  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance (TA)1 for Industrial  Development  in 
Support  of  Yunnan's  Outward-Oriented  Economic  Development  Strategy.  Following 
consultations with the Yunnan provincial government and other stakeholders during 11–13 April 
2012,  a  fact-finding  mission  during  16–17  July  2012  agreed  on  the  objectives,  scope, 
implementation  arrangements,  costs,  and  terms  of  reference  of  the  TA.  The  mission  also 
assessed  the  executing  agency’s  capacity  to  execute  the  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Yunnan has abundant natural resources, hydropower potential, and tourist attractions. 
Geographically, it is strategically located in the southwestern part of the PRC and serves as the 
gateway connecting the country to Southeast and South Asia and beyond. However, Yunnan is 
one of the poorest provinces in the PRC. Promoting Yunnan’s economic development is an 
urgent need to address poverty in the province and promote regionally balanced development in 
the country. Developing Yunnan’s characteristic industries3 with strong growth potential is seen 
as an engine of inclusive growth. Such development needs to capitalize on abundant resources 
and human resource potential and take full advantage of Yunnan being an important land bridge 
to members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and beyond.  
 
3.  Promotion  of  regionally  balanced  development  for  inclusive  growth.  Rapid 
economic growth in the PRC since the onset of economic reforms in 1978 has dramatically 
reduced poverty. The number of absolute poor per PRC poverty standard in rural areas fell from 
250 million in 1978 to just 27 million in 2010, and the incidence of poverty declined from 15% to 
2%.4 However, worsening income inequality has emerged as a serious concern. Income gaps 
have widened between urban and rural areas, and between the eastern coastal and less-
developed central and western regions. 
 
4.  The government has steadily increased investments in a vast array of programs aimed 
specifically at poverty reduction. 5 In February 2012, the State Council announced the Plan for 
Further Promoting the Economy of the Western Regions, a step to narrow the gap between the 
country’s  wealthy  coastal  provinces  and  its  underdeveloped  western  regions.  The  Yunnan 
provincial government has made substantial efforts to accelerate its economic development, as 
stipulated  in  the  Twelfth  Five-Year  Development  Plan  of  Yunnan  Province,  2011–2015. 
However, Yunnan needs to properly orient its development plan and focus development efforts 
on selected characteristic industries to improve its trade competitiveness, and further propel its 
economic development and contribute toward a more regionally balanced and inclusive growth.  
 
                                                
1  The TA is included in the Country Operations Business Plan 2012–2014 for the People’s Republic of China. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 August 2012. 
3  In the PRC, “characteristic industry” commonly refers to an industry or industrial cluster in which a region has 
competitive  advantage.  These  comparative  advantages  or  characteristics  are  developed  from  the  region’s   
specialities in technology, culture, talents, natural resources, geographical location, and ecological environment.      
4  The government revised the poverty line to CNY2,300 per person per annum in November 2011, which has    
resulted in more than 100 million rural persons reclassified as poor. 
5  According to past and current five-year plans for national economic and social development; the China Rural 
Poverty Alleviation and Development Outline, 2001–2010 and 2011–2020; and other policy-related initiatives.

2 
5.  Acceleration  of  outward-oriented  economic  development.  In  July  2009,  the 
President of the PRC proposed to make Yunnan the major gateway for the PRC’s cooperation 
with Southeast and South Asia, and the Mekong River valley. The State Council, in its Opinions 
on Supporting Yunnan Province to Accelerate the Construction of an Important Gateway Open 
to  the  Southwestern  Region  issued  in  May  2011  (the  State  Council  Gateway  Opinions), 
highlighted development of characteristic industries as one of the eight measures, which also 
include strengthening basic infrastructure, optimizing logistics and corridors, deepening trade 
relationships with neighboring countries, protecting the environment, ensuring social services, 
and accelerating poverty alleviation.6 In 2010, Yunnan’s foreign trade increased by 67% where 
34.5% of Yunnan’s total foreign trade was with ASEAN members. The establishment of the 
ASEAN Economic Community by 2015 will create further favorable environment for Yunnan’s 
foreign trade. 
 
6.  Acceleration  of  characteristic  industries  development.  The  Yunnan  provincial 
government  recognizes  the  contribution  of  industrial  development  to  local  and  regional 
economies. It called for accelerating the development of characteristic industries and actively 
mobilizing  financial  sources  in  its  Twelfth  Five-Year  Development  Plan.  Subsequently,  the 
Yunnan provincial Department of Finance (DOF) through its Yunnan Characteristic Industries 
Development and Financial Source Mobilization Action Plan, 2011–2015,7 identified 13 key 
characteristic industries for support.8  
 
7.   However, these selections were based on existing volume of industrial production and 
trade patterns and did not take into account opportunities arising from future trade and supply 
chain development linking Yunnan and ASEAN member countries. Prudent evaluation criteria 
from the perspective of developing an outward-oriented economy need to be applied when 
identifying characteristic industries. A comprehensive and effective strategy for characteristic 
industry development is required to attract investment, encourage private sector participation, 
and promote cross-border trade. In addition, the government needs to upgrade the industrial 
structure to move toward low-carbon and high value-addition part of the production chain.9 
 
8.  The  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  PRC,  2011–201510 promotes  inclusive 
growth with a focus on the lesser-developed interior regions as one of three strategic pillars, 
along with environmentally sustainable growth and regional cooperation and integration. ADB’s 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy supports trade and investment cooperation and 
integration. The TA support complements initiatives led by the PRC and Yunnan province for 
poverty  reduction  and  inclusive,  regionally  balanced  growth  through  characteristic  industry

7   With the cooperation of the Yunnan Academy of Scientific and Technical Information. 
8  Non-ferrous metals, ferrous metals, phosphorus chemicals, biopharmaceuticals, equipment manufacturing, sugar 
processing, grain and oil products, paper processing, beverages, tea products, fruit and vegetable processing, 
livestock poultry processing, and rubber products. The report also proposed five major objectives (developing 
industry;  increasing  fiscal  revenue;  expanding  employment;  stimulating  investment;  and  serving  agriculture, 
farmers and rural areas), three indicators (fiscal revenue reaching 100 million, the germination of initial public 
offerings, and support for enterprises’ expansion), and complementary measures. In the early 1990s, Yunnan 
government announced plans to develop five pillar industries: tobacco, mining, power (mainly hydropower), bio-
industry, and tourism. Priority industries were later selected to include bio-industry, optoelectronics, high-end 
equipment manufacturing, advanced materials, energy conservation and environmental protection, and new energy 
resources for the Twelfth Five-year Plan period.

transport infrastructure development in the region and the free-trade agreement between the 
PRC  and  ASEAN,  and  will  also  help  address  emerging  social  issues  arising  from  the 
accelerated pace of urbanization and industrialization.  
   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be inclusive, regionally balanced growth in the PRC, with 
Yunnan’s outward-oriented economic development as a key part. The attainment of this impact 
will be demonstrated through the establishment of characteristic industry bases, increased trade, 
and higher provincial gross domestic product. The TA outcome is the development strategy for 
selected characteristic industries adopted by the Yunnan provincial government that focuses on 
establishing industrial bases to support outward-oriented economic development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
10.   The TA will help the government identify 3–5 characteristic industries particularly those 
with potential to contribute to Yunnan’s outward-oriented economic development and prepare 
the development strategy for selected characteristic industries. Key activities of the TA will 
proceed in three phases: (i) conducting background studies, (ii) establishing selection criteria 
and prioritizing characteristic industries, and (iii) preparing a strategy and action plan, and 
knowledge products for developing the selected characteristic industries. In the TA inception, a 
workshop  for  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies,  researchers,  and  other  key 
stakeholders will be organized to discuss the TA implementation plan. A seminar or workshop 
will be organized for each phase to disseminate and discuss major findings and implications for 
next steps.  
 
11.  TA outputs will correspond to the three phases: (i) an analysis of Yunnan’s potential to 
develop an outward-oriented economy aimed at industrial integration and trade with ASEAN 
countries, based on studies (i)–(iii) below; (ii) a cost–benefit analysis of adopting policies and 
enabling conditions that will promote selected characteristic industries of Yunnan based on the 
study (iv) below; and (iii) a strategy and action plan for developing and sustainably expanding 
selected  characteristic  industries,  based  on  studies  (v)–(vi)  below.  The  TA  will  deliver  a 
comprehensive report that will comprise six studies on:  
(i)  Yunnan’s  outward-oriented  economic  development  and  industrial 
integration  and  trade  with  members  of  ASEAN.  The  study  will  analyze 
Yunnan’s industrial and trade structures in comparison with those of ASEAN 
countries, assess the outward-oriented economic development strategy in line 
with  the  State  Council  Gateway  Opinions,  recommend  policies  to  promote 
Yunnan’s  outward-oriented  economic  development  and  trade  with  ASEAN 
countries,  and  propose  development  options  for  characteristic  industries  in 
Yunnan. 
(ii)  Characteristic industries’ development in Yunnan. The study will analyze the 
development  of  characteristic  industries  in  Yunnan  in  connection  with  the 
requirements for outward-oriented economic development, analyze their current 
status and trends, identify and explain their contribution to implementation of the 
State  Council  Gateway  Opinions,  and  recommend  policies  to  accelerate  the 
development of Yunnan’s characteristic industries.

4 
(iii)  Case studies of characteristic industries in Yunnan. The studies will select 
typical  characteristic  industries  supporting  outward-oriented  economic 
development; analyze them from the perspectives of the region, industry, and 
enterprise;  identify  factors  for  success  and  constraints;  and  assess  policy 
options.  
(iv)  Establishment of evaluation criteria and methodology and selection of key 
characteristic  industries. The study will analyze the evaluation criteria and 
methodologies  of  comparable  countries for  selecting key  strategic  industries, 
collect and process data using statistical analysis, and prioritize characteristic 
industries through quantitative analysis. 
(v)  Construction of characteristic industrial bases in Yunnan.11 The study will 
propose approaches to constructing industrial bases for selected characteristic 
industries, quantitatively analyze existing data, identify measures to support the 
construction of the characteristic industrial bases, and propose an action plan. 
(vi)  Development strategy for selected characteristic industries. The study will 
offer  key  policy  recommendations,  prepare  a  strategy  and  action  plan,  and 
produce  knowledge  products  to  promote  the  development  of  characteristic 
industries in Yunnan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of office space, counterpart staff, transportation, and 
other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
13.  The executing agency will be the DOF, and the implementing agency will be the Yunnan 
Academy  of  Scientific  and  Technical  Information  (YASTI).12 DOF  will  designate  a  project 
coordinator and will be responsible for the overall execution and coordination of TA activities. 
Under the guidance of DOF, YASTI will be responsible for day-to-day TA implementation. DOF 
and  YASTI  will,  in  coordination  with  ADB,  provide  necessary  guidance  to  consultants, 
particularly to ensure study consistency and avoid any overlap. Consultants will discuss the 
study framework with DOF, YASTI, and ADB and regularly report to them on study progress and 
results.  
 
14.  The TA is included in the list of delegated TA projects for 2012. The fact-finding mission 
reviewed DOF capacity for procurement and managing consulting services for the TA. As only 
individual  consultants  are  intended  to  be  selected,  simplified  capacity  assessment  was 
conducted. The review  found that  DOF  had sufficient  experience  in  implementing  projects 
funded by ADB and the World Bank, including procurement and supervising consulting services 
involving  international  consultants.  The  assessment  concluded  that  DOF’s  capacity  was

12  YASTI is subordinate to the Yunnan Provincial Science and Technology Department but also an independent

adequate to recruit individual consultants, procure goods through shopping procedures, and 
manage the study in cooperation with the implementing agency.13 It recommended approving 
the delegation of the TA to DOF. In line with the enhanced partnership approach,14 delegation is 
limited  to  the  selection  of  international  and  national  consultants,  and  short-term  resource 
persons. ADB will negotiate and sign the contracts with consultants and resource persons. After 
contract signing, implementation is the responsibility of DOF. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 20 months, starting on 1 November 2012 and ending 
on 30 June 2014. The TA will require 4.0 person-months of international consulting services and 
24.5 person-months of national consulting services. The consultants will deliver, in both English 
and  Chinese,  a  comprehensive  report  comprising  six  studies.  They  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The office equipment 
provided  under  the  TA  for  the  consultants  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and handed over to DOF upon 
TA  completion.  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). DOF may use an advance 
payment facility to procure equipment and conduct seminars and workshops. 
 
16.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by DOF and/or YASTI, 
as well as by ADB review missions. Consultants’ reports will be presented at workshops and 
seminars organized to validate findings. Reports will be made available on the ADB website in 
English and Chinese and published in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications Policy 
(2011). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Industrial Development in Support of 
Yunnan’s Outward-Oriented Economic Development Strategy, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General  
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will help the government to identify 3–5 characteristic 
industries—particularly  those  with  potential  to  contribute  to  Yunnan’s  outward-oriented 
economic  development  in  line  with  the  State  Council  Gateway  Opinions—and  prepare  a 
comprehensive development strategy. The TA will be implemented over 20 months, starting in 
November 2012 and ending in June 2014. It will require 4.0 person-months of international 
consulting services and 24.5 person-months of national consulting services. 
 
2.  The consultants will produce six reports in close consultation with the executing agency, 
the Yunnan provincial Department of Finance; the implementing agency, the Yunnan Academy 
of Scientific and Technical Information; and other central, provincial, and local government 
departments and agencies to ensure acceptance of the outcome of the TA. The executing and 
implementing agencies will, in coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB), provide 
guidance to consultants to ensure the consistency of the studies while avoiding overlap. All 
consultants will discuss the study framework with the executing and implementing agencies and 
ADB and regularly report to them on study progress and results. The team leader will be 
responsible for the quality of all outputs and their timely completion.  
 
B.  Consulting Requirements 
1.  Senior  Industrial  Development  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (national,  6 
person-months, intermittent)  
 
3.  The consultant will lead the studies on (i) the evaluation criteria and methodology and 
the selection of key characteristic industries and (ii) the development strategy for selected 
characteristic industries. The consultant should ideally have a master's degree and 10 years of 
experience  in  areas  related  to  industrial  development,  development  economics,  and 
international  trade.  To  serve  as  team  leader,  the  consultant  must  have  demonstrated 
outstanding organizational performance and be proficient in English. His or her responsibilities 
will include the following tasks: 
(i)  guide, coordinate, and supervise the inputs from all team members and take 
responsibility for all study outputs and deliverables; 
(ii)  coordinate closely with relevant government officials and ADB; 
(iii)  organize the inception, midterm, and final report workshops;  
(iv)  set the evaluation criteria and methodology for selecting characteristic industries 
in Yunnan, with the support of the international industrial development specialist;  
(v)  prioritize characteristic and competitive industries suitable for Yunnan based on 
the advice of the international industrial development specialist and technical 
inputs from the national industrial statistician; 
(vi)  finalize the study on the evaluation criteria and methodology and selection of key 
characteristic industries; 
(vii)  analyze  the  background  and  the  basic  conditions  for  characteristic  industry 
development in Yunnan; 
(viii)  propose  appropriate  development  modalities  and  strategies  for  characteristic 
industries in Yunnan; 
(ix)  propose  the  strategic  positioning  and  the  selection  of  strategies,  supporting 
measures, and major action plans for characteristic industry development as part 
of the effort of implementing the State Council Gateway Opinions;

and industrial integration and trade with members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations

(i)  analyze  Yunnan’s  industrial  and  trade  structure  in  comparison  with  ASEAN 
countries, 
(ii)  assess the  outward-oriented  economic  development  strategy  in  line  with  the 
State Council Gateway Opinions, 
(iii)  review other attempts in the People’s Republic of China to engineer an industrial 
base, 
(iv)  provide  policy  recommendations  to  promote  Yunnan’s  outward-oriented 
economic development and trade with ASEAN countries, 
(v)  propose development options for characteristic industries in Yunnan to integrate 
them with those in Southeast Asian countries, and 
(vi)  finalize  the  study  on  Yunnan’s  outward-oriented  economic  development  and 
industrial integration and trade with ASEAN countries. 
 
3.  Characteristic Industries Development Specialist (national, 4 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
5.  The consultant will conduct a study on characteristic industries development in Yunnan. 
He or she should ideally have a master's degree and 7 years of experience in areas related to 
industrial  development  and  development  economics.  Specifically,  the  consultant’s 
responsibilities will include the following tasks: 
(i)  analyze  the  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  threats  regarding 
characteristic  industry  development  in  Yunnan  in  connection  with  the 
requirements of the outward-oriented economic development strategy; 
(ii)  analyze the current status and trends of characteristic industry development in 
Yunnan; 
(iii)  identify and explain characteristic industries’ contributions to implementation of 
the State Council Gateway Opinions; 
(iv)  provide  policy  recommendations  to  accelerate  the  development  of  Yunnan’s 
characteristic industries; and 
(v)  finalize the study on characteristic industries development in Yunnan.

6.  Each consultant will undertake a case study on characteristic industries in Yunnan. The 
consultants should ideally have master's degrees and 7 years of experience in areas related to 
industrial  development  and  development  economics.  Specifically,  the  consultants’ 
responsibilities will include the following tasks:

5.  Industrial Development Specialist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The  consultant  will  provide  advice  and  strategic  inputs  to  the  senior  industrial

consultant should ideally have a master's degree and 7 years of experience in areas related to 
industrial  development  and  development  economics.  Specifically,  the  consultant’s 
responsibilities will include the following tasks: 
(i)  review the background studies and analyze key features of industry development 
in Yunnan, 
(ii)  outline the strategic direction for Yunnan’s industrial development, 
(iii)  analyze comparable countries’ evaluation criteria and methodology for selecting 
key strategic industries, 
(iv)  provide fundamental inputs to the senior industrial development specialist and 
team leader and to the industrial statistician toward establishing the evaluation 
criteria and methodology for selecting characteristic industries in Yunnan, 
(v)  advise  the  national  industrial  statistician  on  applying  evaluation  criteria  and

(vi)  provide inputs for the study on the evaluation criteria and methodology and

6.  Industrial Statistician (national, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.  The consultant will assist the senior industrial development specialist and team leader in 
the study on evaluation criteria and methodology and selection of key characteristic industries. 
In particular, the consultant will quantitatively analyze how to prioritize characteristic industries 
using established evaluation criteria and methodology. The consultant should ideally have a 
master's degree and 7 years of experience in areas related to statistics, econometrics, and 
quantitative  methods.  Specifically,  the consultant’s  responsibilities  will  include  the following 
tasks: 
(i)  participate in establishing the evaluation criteria and methodology for selecting 
characteristic industries in Yunnan, 
(ii)  provide the model analysis, 
(iii)  collect and process data using statistical analysis software, 
(iv)  quantitatively analyze how to prioritize characteristic industries in Yunnan, and

other selected characteristic industrial bases. The consultant should ideally have a master's 
degree and 7 years of experience in areas related to industrial development and industrial
